People really want this police brutality issue to be about race. It's not, 
face that fact. This is police power abuse. They buy fucking military grade 
weaponry from the US military surplus... That ain't racism. Thats wanting 
to be something they're not. They act like an occupational force. NOT a 
policing institute. And you see this all over the US. By the technology 
they use, the weapons they carry, their tactics, etc. For the past 40 years 
they've been taught that outside of the precinct its a battlefield. They 
main objective, was drug warfare. It reflects in all aspects of policing. 
The way they handle suspects, the way they talk to people, they're at war. 
Because Americans wanted it that way. So now that they act like an 
occupational force people get upset. Well this is what your parents or 
grandparents fucking demanded of them. The drug war has completely morphed 
US policing. The drug issue has a fix and is slowly getting better, the 
rest of the country has learned that drug abusers need to seek help, not be 
punished and that drug dealers aren't deserving of life sentences. But the 
police have yet to have reform. Thats the major issue. NOT racism. Racism 
is part of such a small minority of people's ideologies. And if you want to 
talk about institutionalized racism, what about the reverse racism that 
happens when they ask you about what you identify as on college 
applications? Or job applications? When they pick you because your black 
and not because you're a qualified employee. Thats racism. It's like saying 
Asians are all good at math, some might see it as a compliment, BUT IT"S 
WRONG. Not all asians are good at math. Just like not all blacks, not all 
hispanics, not all minorities deserve to go to college because of the color 
of their skin or heritage. The same goes for whites. Not all whites are 
going to be doctors or lawyers. A lot of them are fucking morons, just like 
a lot of black people, a lot of hispanics, a lot of all people are morons 
who'll end up at mid to low tier job positions. It's amazing how people 
just don't see this and they think things are so black and white (no pun 
intended). There is a HUGE grey area that nees to be focused on and we're 
not focusing on it.﻿

+llsa13 You fail to address the issue, come on, look at the worst case 
scenario for a cop, not only for her. You`re being very one sided and not 
considering everything that could happen. It didn`t happen, but imagine if 
it happen! You constantly say "it didn`t happen", "it`s not relevant", 
"don't compare" but I ca and I will bring it all up! Why? Cause if I go to 
hit you in the neck but you see my hit and hit you in the chest instead, 
does it rule out the possibility of me hitting you out in the neck or by 
chance hitting you in the face? Does it take out the possibility that I 
might actually kill you or seriously hurt you? No, it doesn`t. It`s the 
same here. You can say you're not siding with anyone but (quote) "(his 
boss) did and took the appropriate action." suggests you picked your side, 
the side of a drunk woman who assaulted the officer. Now gun-wise, can I 
kill you with my bare hands? Yes. Can I kill you using just my legs? Heck, 
yes I can. Don`t believe me? I don`t wanna kill anyone but I can prove my 
point on a  manikin and a few bones to simulate the impact of a hit that I 
mentioned as the worst case scenario. It doesn`t even have to be an 
intentional kill, it can just happen. So why if a person can kill another 
person in any of the given ways, is it only justifiable to harm a person 
trying to kill you or harm you in only one of the given cases? If he wasn`t 
supposed to return a hit here cause she didn`t do too much harm, why can a 
cop shoot an armed man who hasn`t even shoot a bullet yet, he hasn`t done 
much harm by just holding his gun pointed. And you do know you can compare 
"apples and oranges" as you call them in some aspects? That`s what I did 
here, from a logical aspect, as you said. You shouldn't diss logic and 
possible reactions to actions and possible outcomes because future isn`t a 
fine line and what happens next isn`t written in time, the next second can 
have infinite amounts of possible happenings so take it all into a count. I 
don`t claim that a bullet deserves a bullet, I claim that it`s better to , 
let`s phrase it "stop the disease from spreading than curing it after it 
spreads". If he just put in a few swings and misses with his leg, do you 
honestly think she`d stop? No, if she`s even freaking drunk she`ll feel 
empovered by being able to stand neck to neck with an officer and would be 
encouraged for the next assault, not subdued. There`s one way to make sure 
a person will never make the same mistake again, make them suffer the worst 
possible concequence they can at the given moment. I bet she`ll care if 
she`s gonna get drunk or not next time, and she`ll definitely treat 
officers with more respect, fear driven, but still respect.

+Змај​​​​​​​

At no point have I defended either the officer or the woman. All I've said
